work_exp:
[u"Financial Analyst - Internship
Competitive and Welfare Effects of Cross-Holdings
July 2014 to September 2014
Researched potential loan-seeking companies and forecasted their cash flow; Analyzed the correlations and sensitivities of investment portfolios; Conducted loan credit risk analyses

Research • Competitive and Welfare Effects of Cross-Holdings with Product Differentiation (Dissertation)
Experience Cross-holding takes place when a firm acquires passive ownership in another firm, which entitles the acquiring firm a share in the target firm's profit but not in decision making.
Cross-holding is a common phenomenon in the real world. This paper is the first attempt to analyze competitive and welfare effects of cross-holdings allowing for product differentiation.
I analyze these effects for both substitutable and complementary products under quantity and price competition, respectively. I find that both the strength of the competitive implications

1 of 2
and the conditions resulting in these implications critically depend on the degree of product
differentiation. My analysis has useful empirical and policy applications.
• The Impact of High-Speed Rail on Air Transport in China
High-Speed Rail service (HSR) in China was introduced on April 18, 2007 and has become
immensely popular with an annual ridership of over 1.44 billion in 2016. The HSR network
links the most important metropolitan areas which are also the most important aviation
destinations. I investigate the competition between high-speed rail and air transport in China using Hotelling's location model. I also test whether HSR has significantly changed the frequency and market share of airlines using regression with data at the route level. My
results show that on average, HSR has reduced the number of air transport operations by
24 percent in the route with distance less than 800 km. After the entry of HSR, the air
transport share of the total market is 0.23 points lower.
• Assimilation and Economic Outcomes in the Age of Migration: Evidence from Chinese 1.5
Generation Immigrants
I examine Chinese 1.5 generation immigrants assimilation with respect to language skill
employed in the US labor market across cohorts of childhood immigrants using 2000 IPUMS
data. I use an instrumental variable for English proficiency that is immigrants' age at arrival to analyze the relationship between English proficiency and social assimilation. I find that
English proficiency raises the probabilities of being divorced, marrying a US native, having
a more educated and higher earning spouse, and having fewer children.
• Modified Herfindahl-Hirschman Index and Applications
The traditional Herfindahl-Hirschman index (HHI) is a commonly accepted as a measurement of concentration level in a market. Traditional studies use the change of the HHI to predict
the change of social welfare: changes in the market that cause HHI to rise are thought to be
socially undesirable. However, with cross-holdings HHI might be misleading. The Modified
HHI is proved to be a better measurement of market concentration and is an accepted tool in regulators' assessment of competitive risks imposed by cross-holdings. I demonstrate that
the Modified HHI might also be misleading. I provide necessary and sufficient conditions for when welfare and the Modified HHI to move in opposite directions as one singe firm raises
ownership share in its rivals.
• Competitiveness of Cross-Holdings in Repeated Cournot Oligopolies (joint with Cheng-Zhong
Qin, and Jianxia Yang)
When a firm acquires passive ownership in a rival firm, the acquiring firm competes less
aggressively in static oligopoly models. We show that for a model of repeated Cournot
oligopoly with product differentiation, there is a class of cross-holdings based on empirical
observations that weaken punishments for defecting relative to incentives to defect from collusive agreements. Contrasting to the anticompetitive implications in one-shot Cournot
competition, cross-holdings with only one acquiring firm hinder collusion in repeated Cournot
competition. An implication of this result is that antitrust concerns should not be raised with such cross-holdings. We also discuss sensitivities of the competitiveness of cross-holdings to
product differentiation.", u'Instructor
